Title: Does $f(x) = f(2x)$ for all real $x$, imply that $f(x)$ is a constant function?
Content: If a Continuous function $f(x)$ satisfies $f(x) = f(2x)$, for all real $x$, then does $f(x)$ necessarily have to be constant function? If so, how do you prove it? If not any counter examples?
AcceptedAnswer: For all $x\in\mathbb{R}$ and $n\in\mathbb{Z}$, $f(x)=f(x/2^n)$, so $f(x)=\lim_{n\to\infty}f(x/2^n)=f(0)$ by continuity.
